claim: By around 2035, individuals worldwide should be able to marshal 'unlimited genius'—effectively the cumulative intellectual capacity equivalent to everyone in 2025—making single people more, not less, impactful in the AGI era.
explanation: This is a speculative, extreme prediction not supported by current evidence. Large expert surveys put the median 50% chance for human-level AI around 2047—not ~2035—and emphasize wide uncertainty. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.02843?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) Physical bottlenecks also challenge the idea of “unlimited genius”: analyses forecast high‑quality human text for training could be effectively exhausted between about 2026 and 2032, and the IEA projects data‑centre electricity demand merely doubling by 2030 and, in a high‑adoption scenario, rising to ~1,700 TWh by 2035—large, but hardly indicative of limitless, universally accessible capability. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.04325?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [iea.org](https://www.iea.org/reports/energy-and-ai/energy-demand-from-ai?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) Moreover, “individuals worldwide” having such access is unlikely by 2035 given today’s digital divide (about 2.6 billion people remained offline in 2024). ([itu.int](https://www.itu.int/en/mediacentre/Pages/PR-2024-11-27-facts-and-figures.aspx?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) Overall, the claim overreaches both timeline and feasibility.
